awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to Northwestern University, located in Evanston, IL, will support the training of 8 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2018- 2020. The focus of the program is to provide mentored research experiences to train the next generation of  students in the field of Synthetic Biology. Faculty from the Departments of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Biochemistry and Molecular Genetics, Molecular Biosciences, Engineering Sciences and Applied Mathematics, Biomedical Engineering, Chemistry, and Physics will serve as mentors. After a one-week bootcamp to teach all necessary basic lab techniques, the participating students will carry out an independent synthetic biology research project. Concurrently, students will participate in a carefully designed curriculum to develop skills necessary for success in their future STEM careers, including communication, networking, ethics, and entrepreneurship. This information will be conveyed via seminars, workshops, informal weekly lunches with faculty, social events with other university researchers, and field trips to area companies and museums. At the end of the program, students will present posters describing their projects and results at a research symposium. A stipend will be provided, along with housing, meals, and a travel allowance. Applications will be accepted online, and reviewed by a faculty committee to select participants. Students from underrepresented or underpriviledged groups are encouraged to apply. 

It is anticipated that a total of 24 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences. Continued mentoring will be available to those wishing to pursue additional activities in synthetic biology or related science research.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Additional standard and tailored assessments will be used to refine activities continuously to meet program goals. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting http://synbreu.northwestern.edu , or by contacting the PI (Dr. Tullman-Ercek at ercek@northwestern.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Jewett at m-jewett@northwestern.edu). This award is supported by the Directorate for Biological Sciences (DBI and MCB Divisions) and the Directorate for Engineering (EEC Division).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Northwestern’s Synthetic Biology REU (SynBREU) was established to train the next generation of researchers in fundamental aspects of the important, emerging field of synthetic biology. Synthetic biology tackles problems from sustainability to health, using solutions based on the construction of new, and preprogramming of existing, biological and biology-based systems. Empowering students to succeed requires interdisciplinary, quantitative training in mathematics, engineering and computing in biology. As the intellectual developments of the field accelerate at a rapid pace, there is a growing demand in industry for a workforce of graduates trained in synthetic biology approaches to fuel the continued expansion of this area. SynBREU was carefully designed to develop skillsets necessary for success in future synthetic biology and related STEM careers by integrating communication, design, teamwork, ethics, and entrepreneurship alongside the technical and research training.

The Northwestern Center for Synthetic Biology administered the 10-week program, which hosted 8 students each summer in 2018, 2019, and 2021, and 2 students during summer 2022. Trainees were recruited nationwide, with an emphasis on reaching those from the upper Midwest and at institutions with limited research opportunities in the synthetic biology field. During the period of this award, approximately half of the trainees were from underrepresented groups, approximately one quarter of the trainees were first-generation college students, and more than half of the trainees were women. Moreover, just under half of the interns were enrolled at schools that lacked advanced research opportunities in biological engineering, such as two-year institutions. Over a third of the participants were recruited from institutions in the upper Midwest.

Synthetic biology is being used to engineer solutions to important societal problems, such as the supply of renewable biofuels, biochemicals, and biomaterials, as well as the development and production of diagnostics, vaccines, and therapeutics. Thus, the program enabled broader impacts in the research done, as well as in the training of the workforce to carry out that work. During the program bootcamp, students were trained in the use of a variety of synthetic biology approaches, both computational and experimental, to systematically examine and manipulate biological processes. Trainees were then immersed in hands-on research to integrate engineering principles such as design-build-test-learn cycles and modular design with advanced biological and computational methods. Their independent synthetic biology projects included reviewing literature, designing and carrying out experiments at the bench and/or computationally. Projects were diverse, and included studies in bacteria, yeast, mammalian cells, cell-free systems, artificial cells, and cellular communities. Their work ranged from the modeling of biological systems to engineering RNA, proteins, and synthetic organelles.

The intellectual merit of the program spanned research and pedagogy. Students were actively engaged with synthetic biology at an in-depth, professional and technical level, and mentored by faculty to address critical challenges in the field, from designing sensors for metabolites during sustainable biochemical production to exploring novel viral vectors as vaccine scaffolds. Faculty mentors represented three schools and seven departments, including Chemical and Biological Engineering, Biomedical Engineering, Civil and Environmental Engineering, Chemistry, Cellular and Developmental Biology, Biochemistry and Molecular Genetics, and Pharmacology. To date, there have been three publications in high-impact journals that include one or more trainees as co-authors, as well as numerous conference presentations. Training of the students led to the development of a new scales-based approach to teaching synthetic biology that includes ethics and entrepreneurship embedded into the design of research solutions.

In addition to the full-time research project, the program also emphasized student professional development by facilitating connections to professionals in STEM careers beyond academia via panels and field trips, and providing workshops on topics including ethics of responsible innovation, entrepreneurship, graduate school, and networking. To equip students to share their research findings to the larger community, the program also provided training on science communication to colleagues, collaborators, leadership, and non-scientist stakeholders. This was followed by opportunities to practice and refine these communication skills.

Many SynBREU graduates have gone on to PhD graduate programs. The positive impact of SynBREU alumni and their research on society is invaluable, reflecting the intellectual merit and the broader impacts of synthetic biology at the foundation of the program.
